thread.title: One in four North East exporters are failing to plan for Brexit, report shows

author: Jonathon Manning
title: One in four North East exporters are failing to plan for Brexit, report shows
text:
One in four North East exporters are failing to plan for Brexit, report shows Exporters have seen their sales increase during the third quarter, but are failing to plan for Brexit Share Jack Simpson, policy adviser, North East England Chamber of Commerce Share Get business   Thank you for subscribing!   
North East exporters are being warned they are not doing enough to prepare for Brexit , despite the sector benefiting from strong sales over the last quarter. 
The warning comes as the Quarterly International Trade Outlook is issued by the British Chamber of Commerce, showing how businesses trading overseas have enjoyed strong sales during the last three months, with exporting confidence increasing by 0.5 on the BCC/DHL Trade Confidence Index. 
However, despite the strong growth, 25% of businesses have said Brexit is an issue they are sensitive to, but they were not planning a solution. 
Jack Simpson, policy adviser for the North East England Chamber of Commerce , said: “It is positive news that many exporters are confident about their businesses and have a strong order book. 
“However, it is a concern that a number are not preparing for Brexit and the potential impact on their businesses.” 
“The Chamber is currently working with Square One Law on a project to help prepare supply chain manufacturers for the impact of leaving the EU and this research backs up the urgent need for this support.” 
The value of the pound, which fell following the UK’s vote to leave the EU, was also named by businesses as a major issue over the next 12 months. 
Most firms that responded to the Chamber’s survey said they expected their cost base to increase over the next year, but 52% admitted making no attempt to manage this currency risk. Read More 
Overall exporters have been able to offset their rising costs due to improved sales and heightened overseas demand. Prices remained relatively stable over the period, with the majority of firms reporting no price changes. 
However, more reported a rise in their export prices than a decline. 
While sales have been strong, there is a concern that if the value of the pound once again dips it could lead to major increases in costs. The issue would not only impact the region’s exporters, but would also lead to increased costs for North East importers. 
The report comes after two major businesses in the region both saw their profits shrink, despite adding £40m to their turnover. 
Lawnmower manufacturer Husqvarna and automotive firm Gestamp both blamed their floundering bottom line figures on unpredictable exchange rates. Like us on Facebook
